repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:

LSP spec [states](https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specifications/lsp/3.17/specification/#position) that "if the character value is greater than the line length it defaults back to the line length", but `locations_to_items` gives the error in that case.

Solution:
Adjust locations_to_items to follow the spec.

closes #28281

comment_data.body: can we just modify the above test? this is a lot of (duplicate) code just to test an offset.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2708,6 +2708,42 @@ describe('LSP', function()
       eq(expected, actual)
     end)
 
+    it('location that exceeds the line length returns end_col of line length', function()

comment_data.body:
happy to do that if you prefer @justinmk 

I just thought it was better to leave the test for the "happy path" intact
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2708,6 +2708,42 @@ describe('LSP', function()
       eq(expected, actual)
     end)
 
+    it('location that exceeds the line length returns end_col of line length', function()

comment_data.body:
The type annotation can be avoided by assigning the `local` declaration.

```suggestion
      local ok, col = pcall(_str_byteindex_enc, line, pos.character, offset_encoding)
      if not ok then
        col = vim.fn.strcharlen(line) - 1
      end
      local ok2, end_col = pcall(_str_byteindex_enc, end_line, end_pos.character, offset_encoding)
      if not ok2 then
        end_col = vim.fn.strcharlen(end_line) - 1
      end
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1795,8 +1795,18 @@ function M.locations_to_items(locations, offset_encoding)
       local row = pos.line
       local end_row = end_pos.line
       local line = lines[row] or ''
-      local col = M._str_byteindex_enc(line, pos.character, offset_encoding)
-      local end_col = M._str_byteindex_enc(lines[end_row] or '', end_pos.character, offset_encoding)
+      local end_line = lines[end_row] or ''
+      ---@type boolean, integer, integer
+      local ok, col, end_col
+      ok, col = pcall(_str_byteindex_enc, line, pos.character, offset_encoding)
+      if not ok then
+        col = vim.fn.strcharlen(line) - 1
+      end
+      ok, end_col = pcall(_str_byteindex_enc, end_line, end_pos.character, offset_encoding)
+      if not ok then
+        end_col = vim.fn.strcharlen(end_line) - 1
+      end

comment_data.body:
instead of swallowing errors with pcall() is there an easy way to check that the length is valid? then the code would be clearer and more direct:

```lua
local col = pos.character <= ... and M._str_byteindex_enc(line, pos.character, offset_encoding) or (vim.fn.strcharlen(line) - 1)
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1795,8 +1795,18 @@ function M.locations_to_items(locations, offset_encoding)
       local row = pos.line
       local end_row = end_pos.line
       local line = lines[row] or ''
-      local col = M._str_byteindex_enc(line, pos.character, offset_encoding)
-      local end_col = M._str_byteindex_enc(lines[end_row] or '', end_pos.character, offset_encoding)
+      local end_line = lines[end_row] or ''
+      ---@type boolean, integer, integer
+      local ok, col, end_col
+      ok, col = pcall(_str_byteindex_enc, line, pos.character, offset_encoding)

comment_data.body: I can check if pos.character is larger than the `vim.fn.strcharlen()` of the string but i was trying to avoid calling the len function until it was needed
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1795,8 +1795,18 @@ function M.locations_to_items(locations, offset_encoding)
       local row = pos.line
       local end_row = end_pos.line
       local line = lines[row] or ''
-      local col = M._str_byteindex_enc(line, pos.character, offset_encoding)
-      local end_col = M._str_byteindex_enc(lines[end_row] or '', end_pos.character, offset_encoding)
+      local end_line = lines[end_row] or ''
+      ---@type boolean, integer, integer
+      local ok, col, end_col
+      ok, col = pcall(_str_byteindex_enc, line, pos.character, offset_encoding)

comment_data.body:
that's a good practice for sure. but adding a `character` param to the `exec_lua` call in the above tests, would allow us to make one extra call with character=10000. 

so that allows testing the happy path as well as some variants. and it's clearer for others to follow, because it's only ~one call instead of 30+ lines of code :)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2708,6 +2708,42 @@ describe('LSP', function()
       eq(expected, actual)
     end)
 
+    it('location that exceeds the line length returns end_col of line length', function()

comment_data.body: true. i think it's probably worth it though. pcall() can hide other kinds of errors, which would make other bugs hard to find.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1795,8 +1795,18 @@ function M.locations_to_items(locations, offset_encoding)
       local row = pos.line
       local end_row = end_pos.line
       local line = lines[row] or ''
-      local col = M._str_byteindex_enc(line, pos.character, offset_encoding)
-      local end_col = M._str_byteindex_enc(lines[end_row] or '', end_pos.character, offset_encoding)
+      local end_line = lines[end_row] or ''
+      ---@type boolean, integer, integer
+      local ok, col, end_col
+      ok, col = pcall(_str_byteindex_enc, line, pos.character, offset_encoding)

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
              -- LSP spec: if character > line length, default to the line length.
              ['end'] = { line = 1, character = 10000 },
```

```suggestion
      -- LSP spec: if character > line length, default to the line length.
      -- https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specifications/lsp/3.17/specification/#position
      local col = pos.character <= line_len
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1795,8 +1795,16 @@ function M.locations_to_items(locations, offset_encoding)
       local row = pos.line
       local end_row = end_pos.line
       local line = lines[row] or ''
-      local col = M._str_byteindex_enc(line, pos.character, offset_encoding)
-      local end_col = M._str_byteindex_enc(lines[end_row] or '', end_pos.character, offset_encoding)
+      local line_len = vim.fn.strcharlen(line)
+      local end_line = lines[end_row] or ''
+      local end_line_len = vim.fn.strcharlen(end_line)
+      local col = pos.character <= line_len

title: fix(lsp): handle locations exceeding line length
